Award.AwardTitle: Think Globally, Learn Locally (TGLL): Neighborhood Ecology in a Global Perspective

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
PROJECT ABSTRACT FOR UTAH GK-12 GRANT

The Think Globally, Learn Locally: Neighborhood Ecology in a Global Perspective (TGLL) program is a collaboration involving graduate students and faculty from the Departments of Biology, Geology & Geophysics, Atmospheric Sciences (formally Meteorology) and the Utah Museum of Natural History, together with teachers and students from elementary schools in the Salt Lake City School District. TGLL will train 9 Graduate Fellows per year to develop and lead Inquiry-Based Activities (IBAs) for fourth, fifth and sixth grade students. These activities will focus on five major environmental issues: (1) habitat alteration, (2) pollution and disturbance, (3) invasive species, (4) climate change, and (5) disease. Students will learn the science behind these issues, their practical implications, and how individual lifestyle choices scale up to affect the relevant processes on a global scale. TGLL Fellows will serve as scientific role models and mentors to young students at a critical stage of their intellectual and emotional development, and will show them how to become citizen scientists with the outlook and preparation needed to engage productively with complex, emerging environmental issues.
The TGLL program will make science accessible to a wide audience by targeting schools and neighborhoods with high minority populations and actively recruit TGLL Fellows from underrepresented groups. The IBAs developed in the TGLL program will be integrated with the Science Core Curriculum of the State of Utah for fourth, fifth and sixth grades. By working with TGLL Fellows K-12 teachers will gain confidence in scientific teaching, and become active members of a research and teaching network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Utah NSF GK-12 program Think Globally, Learn Locally (PI Donald H. Feener Jr.) was active May 2009 to April 2016. This program (TGLL) placed graduate student fellows from STEM departments (Anthropology, Atmospheric Sciences, Biology, Geography and Geology & Geophysics) in K-12 classrooms as science mentors in the Salt Lake City School District. TGLL focused on five environmental issues with both local (Salt Lake City area) and global effects. These issues were: 1) climate change, 2) invasive species, 3) infectious disease 4) habitat alteration, and 5) pollution. TGLL's goal was to teach critical thinking skills to 4th to 12th grade students regarding these issues so that they could see how they are interrelated and how the students' activities at the local scale can have global consequences. The program focused mostly on majority-minority schools on the west side of the Salt Lake Valley.

The TGLL program trained a total of 40 graduate student fellows (and 6 undergraduate student fellows). Twenty-two graduate fellows were women and 5 were from underrepresented groups (African American, American Indian and Hispanic). Fellows received training in pedagogy from teaching professionals, science communication from a variety of experts, and interdisciplinary collaboration by working together on K-12 classroom projects. Fourteen of these fellows are still in graduate school, 11 have assumed postdoctoral or faculty positions, 2 are K-12 teachers, 5 are employed by NGOs or government, 5 are in the private sector and 3 are in unknown positions.

During the tenure of the program 60 K-12 teachers participated as classroom mentors for the TGLL graduate fellows. Fellows developed and documented over 300 activity-based learning modules, 40 of which are currently available online to K-12 teachers statewide through the Utah Education Network (www.uen.org). Over 9,000 K-12 students participated in the TGLL program. Students engaged in activities that included classroom experiments and outdoor field studies along the Jordan River, at the Great Salt Lake and the Red Butte Botanical Gardens, and up Big Cottonwood and Little Cottonwood Canyon. TGLL in collaboration with Department of Chemistry at the University of Utah also developed the "Science Friday" program, in which high students would travel to the university on selected Fridays and engage in analytical chemistry projects, such as the quantification of capsaicin in various kinds of chiles. TGLL also arranged for K-12 students to visit the University of Utah to present the results of their activities and projects at formal scientific poster sessions. STEM graduate students and faculty, college deans and the Vice President for Research attended these poster sessions and were encouraged to ask questions of the K-12 students. The goal of these poster sessions was to give K-12 students "ownership" of their knowledge and demonstrate to them that they have something to offer the university. Surveys at the beginning and end of the school year indicated that participation in the TGLL program improved both STEM content knowledge of K-12 students and their attitude toward science in general.
